Spiced potatoes and spinach

1.5kg fresh spinach
3 medium onions
1 thumb-sized piece fresh ginger
8 cloves garlic
1 fresh hot chilli
8 tbsp vegetable oil
2kg good, large waxy potatoes
1 medium cauliflower 1 stick cinnamon
7 whole cloves
7 whole cardamom pods
2 bayleaves
2 tbsp ground coriander
1 tbsp ground cumin
1 tsp ground turmeric
1 large tomato
2 tbsp plain yoghurt
Sea salt
1 tbsp garam masala

Remove any excess stalk and damaged leaves from the spinach. Bring a large pan of lightly salted water to the boil, plunge in the spinach and leave to cook for one minute. Transfer it to a bowl of iced water, or lay on flat trays to drain and cool. Squeeze the spinach dry. Peel and rinse the potatoes. Cut them into large wedges and rinse again.

Separate the cauliflower into florets. Blanch and peel the tomato, then roughly chop. Peel and roughly chop the onions, ginger, chilli and garlic. Put them in a liquidiser, with five tablespoons of water, and whizz to a paste.

Place a large, heavy-bottomed pot over a medium heat and pour in the vegetable oil. Add all the whole herbs and spices, fry for 10 seconds, then add the paste, lower the heat and fry for 10 minutes more, until darkened slightly. Add the ground spices and fry for a further five minutes, adding a drop of water now and then if the mixture sticks to the base of the pan. Tip in the tomato and yoghurt, stir, then add the potatoes and cauliflower, and stir until coated. Roughly chop the spinach, and add this to the pot, too. Pour in enough water to come just below the surface of the vegetable mass, and cover with a lid. Turn off the heat and leave to cool for 40 minutes, keeping the lid on, then remove the lid and simmer again, not too gently, until most of the liquid has reduced and the sauce is thickened. Dust the surface of the stew with garam masala and stir in, taking care not to break up the vegetables.

Chocolate chinchilla

Culled from Elizabeth David, cheering the match of cinnamon and chocolate.

7 egg whites
60g unsweetened cocoa powder
90g caster sugar
1 heaped tsp ground cinnamon

Pre-heat the oven to 160C/325F/gas mark 3. Butter a ring mould or, even better, a kugelhopf mould or, better still, a steamed pudding mould with a central funnel and clip-on lid. Sieve together the cocoa, sugar and cinnamon into a big bowl. In another scrupulously cleaned bowl, whip the egg whites until peaked and stiff.

Cook in the middle of the oven for 45-50 minutes. It will rise in a spectacular manner and, upon cooling, sink in even more spectacular a fashion unless, the moment you take it from the oven, you leave the mould to cool in a warm place well protected from draughts and any sudden changes in temperature. When cold, the pudding, although shrunken from its just-baked glory, will have become compact enough to turn out easily. It is best served with just-whipped cream enlivened with a little sugar and rum.

Cinnamon flavours ice cream very well - and makes a perfect partner for plums in tarts or crumbles.

520ml double cream
280ml good milk
2 cinnamon sticks
1 ball allspice
1 clove
120g caster sugar
4 egg yolks

Roughly break up the cinnamon and add it to the milk, along with the clove and allspice. Heat the milk, but do not let it come to a boil. Cloves

In the 16th century the Alps were as distant from the normal world as was the moon. To many they represented hell, combing the freezing conditions of a Nordic Niflheim , the Nordic mythological underworld, with, in summer, the roasting inferno of Christianity. Here was a realm whose upper reaches were, by all accounts, home to a race of malformed and malevolent sub-humans. The peaks above were inhabited by demons and witches were well attested. It was an undisputed fact that dragons lived in Alpine caves, ready to incinerate any who set foot above the snowline. By the late 18th century, however, scientific gentlemen began to turn their minds to these high places. What would the peaks tell us about the atmosphere, about weather, about glaciers?

In the 19th century the British came on the scene, full of imperial confidence and set out to plant their flag on every peak in the Alps. The Matterhorn disaster of 1865 was one of those tragic events of which the Victorians were so fond and to which they were so prone. It ranked in popular imagination alongside Franklin's disappearance in the Arctic andLivingstone's death in Africa. It shaped the childhood perceptions of millions and it had, uniquely, a survivor who could describe it at first hand. Edward Whymper, who was only in his mid-20s at the time of the disaster, was bedevilled by it for the rest of his life

On July 12 1865 Whymper, a printer and Alpinist, was in the small village of Breuil at the foot of the unconquered Matterhorn. He was woken with the news that an Italian party - led by the guide Jean-Antoine Carrel, whom Whymper thought he had hired to climb the mountain - had begun an ascent.

Whymper was furious. He had been "bamboozled and humbugged". He snatched a telescope and peered through it. Yes, there was Carrel and his party, making their way up the lower slopes. But his group was large and unwieldy. It would take them three days to reach a position from which they could tackle the summit. If he moved fast, Whymper could be in Zermatt inside a day and, conditions willing, could be on the summit two days later. But he had no guide. Miraculously, Whymper was saved by the arrival of Lord Francis Douglas, an "exceedingly amiable and talented" 18-year-old whose brother, the Marquess of Queensberry, would later instigate the Oscar Wilde trial.

Douglas was no stranger to daring exploits: he had scaled the walls of Edinburgh castle aged 14, and had swum the Hellespont aged 16. Although not an experienced mountaineer, he had done some fine climbing that season and had in tow Young Peter Taugwalder, namesake and son of Old Peter Taugwalder from Zermatt.

Father and son had carved themselves a reputation for leading tourists up the easier slopes. Old Peter had reconnoitred the north-east ridge of the Matterhorn and was convinced, like Whymper, that it was surmountable. Whymper was immediately interested. Did Douglas truly want to climb the Matterhorn from Zermatt? Yes. Could Young Taugwalder carry their gear there? Douglas agreed and the next day the two Englishmen went down to the Monte Rosa hotel in Zermatt, where they instructed Old Peter Taugwalder to prepare for an immediate attack on the Matterhorn.

The Rev Charles Hudson, and his protégé, Douglas Hadow, were also staying in the Monte Rosa and were also planning to climb the Matterhorn. Whymper and Hudson agreed that it would be wasteful for two separate teams to go up the Matterhorn. Hudson, vicar of Skillington in Lincolnshire, was the glamorous face of British mountaineering. He was a handsome, cheerful man. Young women stuck his photograph in their albums, from where it smiled out romantically above a dashing signature. But at the same time he was entirely self-effacing. "Although he had done the greatest mountaineering feats which have been done, he was the last to speak of his own doings." Hadow was a different proposition. He was 19, and it was his first season in the Alps. In such a large expedition, the group was dependent on its weakest member. Hadow was indisputably the weakest member.

For Hudson and Whymper, the Matterhorn was so much easier than they had expected that, on the morning of July 13, they led the way, taking turns to hack steps in the ice while the guides hung back. When they made camp on a ledge at 11,000 feet they were almost delirious. Croz, an experienced guide, and Young Peter Taugwalder scouted ahead and returned with the news that there was "not a difficulty, not a single difficulty!... We could have gone to the summit and returned today easily!" Everybody went to bed in good spirits. The next day Whymper handed the lead to Croz. The rocks were testing in places, and extremely exposed, but Whymper thought it a lot easier than other climbs. He was worried, however, by Hadow, who "was not accustomed to this kind of work and required continual assistance".

They went up and up, crossing 400 feet horizontally here, ascending 60 feet vertically there, then doubling back to a convenient ridge when their way was blocked. There was an awkward corner and finally they were there, separated from the summit by 200 feet of snow. "The last doubt vanished!" Whymper wrote, "The Matterhorn was ours!" Whymper ran along the ridge. Peering over the edge, he saw his Italian rivals some 1,250 feet below, crawling like ants up the hillside. He and Croz yelled and waved their arms, to no apparent effect. "We must make them hear us; they shall hear us," Whymper cried. He seized a block of stone and hurled it down. Croz joined him and together they wrestled lumps of crag down the cliff. Whymper crowed: "The Italians turned and fled."

Then came the flag-planting. One of the tent poles had been removed that morning - against Whymper's protestation that they were tempting providence - and it was now embedded on the northern end of the ridge with Croz's shirt tied to it as a flag. It was visible from all directions.

Down in Breuil, convinced that their group had succeeded, the inhabitants came out en fete, toasting Carrel, Italy and the Matterhorn. It was only when the dejected team arrived home that they learned their mistake. "It is true," said the Italians. "We saw them ourselves - they hurled stones at us! The old traditions are true - there are spirits on the top of the Matterhorn!"

Around 3pm on July 14, Hudson and Whymper agreed on their order of descent. While they were roping up, Whymper spent a last few minutes sketching the summit and then, darting back up to put their names in a bottle, he took his place in the chain. The adrenalin which had carried them to the top was gone, leaving them shaky-legged and exhausted. They took exaggerated care on the rocks they had bounded up so eagerly that morning. Hadow, who was the weariest of them all, had his feet guided into position by Croz. Their precautions were standard practice for any well guided party coming home after a new conquest, save for one important difference - although the leaders were tied to one of the stronger ropes, Old Peter and Douglas were linked by the weakest of the lot.

Croz put his axe to one side so that he could assist Hadow on a tricky slope. What occurred next could only be guessed at. Whymper's theory was that Croz had helped Hadow into a safe position and had then turned round to pick up his ice axe. As he did so, Hadow slipped and knocked Croz over. Whymper did not see it happen, his view being blocked momentarily by a rock, but he witnessed every moment of the subsequent tragedy.

"I heard one startled exclamation from Croz, then saw him and Mr Hadow flying downwards; in another moment Hudson was dragged from his steps, and Lord F Douglas immediately after him. All this was the work of a moment. Immediately we heard Croz's exclamation, Old Peter and I planted ourselves as firmly as the rocks would permit: the rope was taut between us and the jerk came on us both as one man. We held; but the rope broke midway between Taugwalder and Lord Francis Douglas. For a few seconds, we saw our unfortunate companions sliding downwards on their backs, and spread ing out their hands, endeavouring to save themselves. They passed from our sight uninjured, disappeared one by one, and fell from precipice to precipice on to the Matterhorngletscher below, a distance of nearly 4,000 feet. From the moment the rope broke, it was impossible to help them."

Whymper and the two Taugwalders did not move for half an hour. Old Peter burst into tears. Young Peter cried, "We are lost! We are lost!" With difficulty Whymper persuaded Young Peter to leave his perch - they were still roped together and unless he moved they were stuck - then guided father and son back to Zermatt. They went down slowly and carefully, searching for their companions' bodies as they went, sometimes calling out in the vain hope that one of them might have survived. Whymper later wrote to a friend. "For two hours after the accident I thought every moment that the next would be my last... the two guides were unnerved to such an extent that I suspected every minute one or the other would have slipped, and then it would have been all over."

At 9.30pm, Whymper chose "a wretched slab, barely large enough to hold the three", on which to spend the night. Six hours later there was enough moonlight for them to continue the descent. They went down in silence, met the first chalets, and then ran all the way to Zermatt. Whymper burst into the Monte Rosa hotel and made for his room, pursued by an inquisitive landlord. As he closed the door he announced "The Taugwalders and I have returned."

The landlord roused the village and 20 men went on their way to the base of the north face. When they reached the scene they found Croz and Hadow lying next to each other on the snow, with Hudson some 50 yards distant. The bodies had been stripped almost naked during the fall and were so battered that they were barely recognisable - Croz was missing the top half of his head and was identified only by his beard and by a rosary cross. Of Douglas there was no trace, save a pair of gloves, a belt and a boot. His body had either caught on a ledge or had been shredded as it bounced from rock to rock. Apart from a single coat sleeve, nothing more was ever found of him.

The news broke slowly, inaccurately and piecemeal. Whymper wrote a description of the tragedy in the visitors' book of the Monte Rosa, which was stolen almost immediately, but it was August 8 before he published a definitive account in the Times. Until then, wild rumours circulated that made Zermatt, briefly, the most famous place in Europe. Climbers from every nation rushed to the village, impelled by the desire to help, to offer condolences or simply to gawp.

On July 19, the British consul in Geneva sent his chaplain to conduct a private inquiry and on July 21, Zermatt opened its own inquest. Midway through its deliberations, a wrenchingly ignorant telegram arrived from Douglas's mother, Lady Queensbury: "Is it not possible to seek in the rocks above or to let down food?"

Meanwhile, Whymper was giving his deposition to the local court. He told everything as it had happened and blamed the fall entirely on the use of the weak rope. Looking at the piece he had retained as evidence, the officials accepted his deposition without question. It was flimsy beyond belief and had clearly snapped. (Sections of all three ropes are preserved in Zermatt's Alpine museum. The one that broke is little thicker than a washing line.) The verdict was accidental death.

What was not explained (or asked), however, was why the weak rope had been used in the first place. Whymper threw out diversionary leads, blaming Hudson for having allowed Hadow to be a member of the party and hinting at a conspiracy within Zermatt's judicial system. Hadow's father thought Whymper had gone too far in abrogating all responsibility. "We have been greatly distressed at Mr Whymper's letter in the Times and the leading article which I was sure would follow," he wrote on August 10. "He might have spared those unnecessary remarks about poor Hudson, which have brought blame on him for want of prudence and caution." Emily Hudson, Charles Hudson's wife, felt the same. Lurid reports were already circulating and she was angry that Whymper should have cast her husband as the wrongdoer. "I cannot tell you how it has distressed me," she wrote. "I am very much surprised that Mr Whymper should have been a party to it. Of course one knows the craving there is in the public mind for the sensational, in any form; but it really makes me sick to think of such a subject being used to gratify their tastes."

Whymper was released from the inquest on July 22 1865 and came home to find himself the most talked-about person in London. A fellow Alpine club member wrote that he was "most truly to be pitied, for his name is so connected with the Matterhorn, and rather wild designs upon it, that people are sure to blame him for the accident".

Until that year, fatalities in the Alps had been relatively rare, something for the exploring community to remark upon; after that date they became commonplace. In 1870 an entire party of 11, led by a Scot, the Rev G MacCorkendale, got lost in a blizzard and perished on Mont Blanc. The bodies of six of the climbers were never found. As the fatalities increased, Queen Victoria's private secretary wrote to prime minister Gladstone, "The Queen commands me to ask you if you think she can say anything to mark her disapproval of the dangerous Alpine excursions which... have occasioned so much loss of life."

The Matterhorn disaster shaped the remainder of Whymper's life. Never very sociable, he withdrew still further. According to his sister, "his unfortunate habit of sleeplessness had become fixed, and he practically turned night into day". His main preoccupation was writing up his journals for publication. But he did not stop exploring: he made two expeditions to Greenland, he climbed new peaks in the Andes and the Rockies and, his funds having been exhausted by these forays, wrote guidebooks to Zermatt and Chamonix. He received the Royal Geographical Society's gold medal and was proposed for - but was not granted - membership of the Royal Society. The disaster was a topic he returned to again and again in lecture halls, magazine articles and private correspondence for the 46 years until his death, but he seemed interested only in proving that he was not to blame.

Whymper's relations with women had not been successful, but in 1899 he fell in love with Charlotte Hanbury, one of the few women climbers active in the Alps. She was 10 years his senior and died unexpectedly the following October. The news reached him just as he was starting a lecture tour in America. "My beloved friend gone!" he wrote to his sister. "I hardly know how to carry on."

His health began to deteriorate and he became prone to unexpected collapses that left him in a state of semi-consciousness. In 1905 a fall on a mountain path damaged several ribs; he received a severe blow to the head in a railway accident. "My present condition is deplorable," he wrote in October. "My memory has gone !... [I am] a Wreck without Brains." His memory returned but he was concerned that he was losing fitness and, when he visited Zermatt a few weeks after the crash, it appeared that he was losing his fame as well. It was freezing, nobody was there to greet him and the hotels were full: he drew together two station benches and slept on them under a rug.

The next year, at the age of 66, he married Edith Mary Lewin of Forest Gate, London. She was 45 years younger than him. The wedding was a grisly occasion, conducted in great secrecy. At the wedding breakfast it took half an hour's persuasion before Whymper could be dragged out of his bedroom. McCormick, the presiding vicar, gave a leery address about the difference in their ages. When the wedding was over, Whymper told his nephew, the only member of his family invited to the ceremony, to search the guests in case they had stolen the silver.

The union did not last. The couple had a daughter and divorced in 1910. The separation was bitter. "Her sole aim is money," he wrote to his sister. He sold his house, his books and even his climbing equipment to stay financially afloat. The following year he visited Zermatt, from where he went to Geneva and then up to Chamonix. It was to be his last Alpine scramble, and perhaps he knew it.

At Chamonix he checked into a hotel where the staff were accustomed to his preference for being left alone. He visited a few bookshops and made arrangements to help find the corpses from the 1870 Mont Blanc disaster which were expected soon to emerge from the glacier. Then, suddenly, went back to his hotel and locked himself into his room. During the next two days, Whymper died. The whole village turned out to watch his funeral.

All the great mountains were subsequently conquered one by one, by insouciant public schoolboys and dogged tradesmen alike. By the end of the second world war the Alps had changed irrevocably. Ski resorts proliferated as entrepreneurs devoured the empty spaces.

Gradients were bulldozed and forests were cut down to create pistes. Ropes were pinned to the Matterhorn to make life easier for those wishing to conquer the Big Rock. This well-groomed wilderness was no place for dragons. Yet its upper levels retained a strange fascination. Climbers still strode across passes, clambered over glaciers and struggled with dangerous new routes. Far fewer in number than the thousands who rushed to the Alps every winter, they preserved a glimmer of the old romance. Like their predecessors, they were trespassers in a hostile environment; they were adventurers in an old tradition.

Oscar Wilde famously claimed for himself a symbolic relationship with his historical epoch. And with some reason: for more than 10 years, certainly from 1890 to 1900, what you thought about Wilde was a reliable indicator of what you thought and felt about a whole range of emotive issues, ranging from specifics such as sodomy, interior decoration and the West End to more obscure yet fundamental notions of cultural and personal identity. His rise and fall made a front-page drama out of the meanings of masculinity and effeminacy, respectability and fashion, and modernity itself. This symbolic status has not faded over the intervening 100 years. Wilde has continued to function as a kind of cultural litmus test, his name a shorthand for all kinds of surprising allegiances.

Every decade of the last century found a different way of using Wilde to express its own concerns. In the era when his name was literally considered unspeakable, at least in this country, paperback copies of The Ballad of Reading Gaol and The Soul of Man under Socialism were badges of political radicalism. Meanwhile Strauss's operatic Salome of 1905 maintained Wilde's reputation as the ne plus ultra of decadence. EM Forster's Maurice, cowering unpublished in the closet in 1914, miserably branded himself "an unspeakable of the Oscar Wilde sort". Each of the very different theatrical and film Wildes reinvented him in turn as the image of their own times. In the 1970s, his name was taken in vain by a new kind of badge-wearer; a popular button among stroppier queens of Liberation-era London read simply "Avenge Oscar". In our own time Stephen Fry, launching a film that, despite noble intentions, gave us the Wildean pill sugared with a 1990s mix of cost-free sympathy and celebrity, unblushingly compared Wilde to Christ.

So to what new uses will this brilliant and fascinating artist be put in our new, millennial and - as you have no doubt noticed - centenary decade? Who is Wilde now, in the year 2000? Sadly these two new titles, optimistically published to cash in on the festivities, fail to discover any new echoes or resonances in the magic name. The only sound generated is the rather ugly one of the barrel being scraped. Greedy publishers and lazy editors, rather than the poor besotted authors, must, I think, take the primary blame for this. Both Barbara Belford and Joan Schenkar have, in their different ways, fallen under the Wilde spell; but Virago and Bloomsbury might have done well to dampen or at least discipline their infatuations.

The idea of a new biography so soon after Richard Ellmann's magisterial heavyweight has an appealing chutzpah. Indeed, Belford is right to take him to task for his omissions, and my hopes rose when she promised to illuminate Wilde anew by grounding him securely in the context of both homosexual life and theatrical practice in the late 19th century. The problem is, she doesn't deliver. Although she repeatedly mentions that Wilde had sex with other men, she does nothing with the available historical facts. Picturesque but unsubstantiated speculation that things may have been rather neoclassical between the sheets - early exposure to Graeco-Roman statuary in the National Gallery of Ireland having led directly to intercrural copulation with Robbie Ross in the study at Tite Street in 1887 - really won't do.

Her account of late Victorian theatre is hopelessly clogged with irrelevant detail. I was happy to be told that the New York theatre was revolutionised in 1882 by Steele Mackage's invention of the tip-up seat, but unsure what this had to do with Wilde's attempts to stage a hit there. The effect of ill-digested research is pervasive: there are lots of things that need to be said about Wilde's father, but was such a dramatic account of his illegal acquisition of a set of mummified ibis ("sacred, long-legged, white wading birds") while on holiday in Egypt really necessary? Despite the promise that this is a "fresh look" at Wilde, the only really distinctive thing about this book is Belford's occasionally startling turn of phrase. I was frankly amazed to learn that in fin de siècle Algeria "boys showed their availability by scrambling up men's trousers". Belford claims that she has spent five years "getting to know the inner Wilde", and that the familiar material is delivered "with a new, centenary spin". Truth is, this is just a rehash: she has nothing new to say, and says it clumsily.

Joan Schenkar can at least claim to be first in the queue. Her contribution to the Wilde centenary is an oblique one: the first biography of Oscar's previously undocumented niece, Dolly. Although Dolly is the ostensible subject, Uncle is named at least once on every page; the constant comparison and overshadowing matches that which dogged Dolly all her life. By the time she hit the saloons of 1920s Paris, she was the last Wilde. This was her entrée, and she made a point of talking and looking like her uncle whenever she could. She was, according to girlfriends, both a notable wit and an uncannily convincing lookalike when in Oscar drag. Trouble is, she was precious little else; she took a perverse pride in never writing a word of fiction despite constant assurances that she was destined for literary greatness by virtue of the family aura. True, she dined with, borrowed from, insulted or slept with almost everyone in the astonishing rue Jacob lesbian salon, sliding into major addictions (fast cars, drink, drugs and "emergency seductions") before ending up face-down in a rented Belgravia flat at the age of 46. But while simultaneously injecting under the table and dishing the dirt on duchesses may have been chic, it hardly adds up to a career.

Schenkar tries hard to argue that this absence of achievement is itself significant, and that underneath the surface dazzle of proto-It Girl outrage there is a serious book about how the Wildean iconography of self-destruction was replayed in a feminine, feminist, modern and modernist world. I wasn't convinced. The opening chapters are spirited and inventive, but although this biographer is commendably besotted by her subject, and often stylishly successful in evoking an extraordinary lost world of Vionnet frocks and detox clinics, Dolly quickly began to pall. Her uncle's achievement was to lodge himself, for better or for worse, permanently in the public imagination. Dolly lived off his myth, rather than substantially elaborating or elucidating it. The same, I'm afraid, might be said for both these biographies.

 Neil Bartlett's new play about Wilde, In Extremis, is at the National Theatre.

Civilizations

Felipe Fernandez-Armesto

636pp, Macmillan

£25
Buy it at BOL

Civilization is a knotty word. The good Doctor Johnson, for example, was not about to let it through the hallowed portals of his Dictionary, as Boswell tells us: "He would not admit civilization, but only civility. With great deference to him, I thought civilization, from to civilize, better in the sense opposed to barbarity, than civility."

Today we no longer reach so comfortably for words like "barbarity". But, as Boswell rightly points out, the word "civilization" is derived from the verb "to civilize", so what it can usefully denote is a process rather than a congealed achievement. Civilization, properly, is the process of rendering a society more civil. It is a political concept, deriving ultimately from the Latin "civis", citizen of a community, and the idea of what is proper to a citizen, which is "civilitas" or courtesy. It is in this sense that a beautifully sardonic Gandhi murmured that western civilization "would be a good idea".

Felipe Fernandez-Armesto, however, claims to believe that the idea of a civilizing "process" - whereby societies might learn to live together more peacefully and productively - is tainted irrevocably by the horrors of 20th-century dreams of "progress": fascism and Soviet communism. This is rampant nonsense. The fact that some dreams of progress have been wicked is no good reason to abandon the idea of progress itself. It is undeniable that universal suffrage and the abolition of the death penalty have contributed to the civilization of this country in the past century. And we ought constantly to demand more civilization, rather than to abandon the idea completely out of a misguided world-historical pessimism.

But then, the key to understanding the deliberate eccentricity of Fernandez-Armesto's book lies in his hysterical anti-liberalism. He is a man complacently "waiting for the conservative nirvana", and seriously claims at the book's climax that "liberal principles become the forerunners of death camps and eugenics". Such nasty pottiness bookends this fat work: at the start, he smears the work of Arnold Toynbee with the following disgustingly uncivil innuendo: "Toynbee's enthusiasm for 'pioneer' leaders, steering civilization towards collective goals, seems chilling in a work published just after Hitler came to power." Another theorist of civilization, Kenneth Clark, is dismissed for what Fernandez-Armesto calls his "warped perspective". But Clark's perspective - his preference for a marble Apollo over an African mask - was no more "warped" than any other: it was simply a perspective. It would seem hard, indeed, to write from no perspective at all; unless, perhaps, you can attain the godlike objectivity of a Fernandez-Armesto.

Our author's claim is that civilization is fundamentally a measure of how man refashions his environment to his own ends. He solicits both praise for this idea's novelty ("This is an experimental work ... meant to be ... unprecedented") and respect for its venerability ("The usage I advocate is justified by tradition"), thus setting a rigorously maintained precedent of having his cake and eating it. He notices that Toynbee had the idea in 1919, but dismisses his formulation on a technicality and then conveniently forgets about it. He promises grandly that his revolutionary new recategorisation will open up fresh vistas of historical truth.

Up to a point. The central 500 pages are devoted to a grand tour of world history by environment: hostile wastelands of desert, tundra and ice; swathes of uncultivable grassland; tropical and temperate forests; alluvial soils; highlands, islands and "seaboard civilizations". The plurality of the book's title emphasises that civilization is not confined to western Europe or other lucky pockets of geography: human ingenuity ensures that it happens pretty much anywhere humans can stay alive. Great structures have been built in rebarbative rainforest or on shifting mud. Fernandez-Armesto's scheme enables pretty juxtapositions (the Aztecs, Ethiopians and Tibetans are seen to have overcome similar problems of altitude) and provocative revaluations (the Aztecs, again, seem more heroically competent in "civilizing" their environment than the classical Greeks).

But Fernandez-Armesto, in the interest of covering all bases, is so systematically self-contradictory as to be almost comically incoherent. Environment shapes civilization; no, it doesn't; yes, it does; er, OK then, civilizations are "neither determined nor uninfluenced by environment". Well, who is going to argue with that? Temporary and mutually exclusive criteria of civilizational "success" flash past. The Inuit, for example, are less "civilized" than modern Europeans because they have adapted themselves to their icy environment rather than attempting to change it; then again, maybe civilization would be an "irrational strategy" in such terrain, "at least where long-term survival is the goal". But if long-term survival really were a valid criterion, that would imply that the Inuit have been more successful than, say, the imperial Romans, because the Inuit are still here.

Fernandez-Armesto's definition of what sort of behaviour constitutes "civilizing" an environment becomes so loose at times - just eating bits of it and constructing ramshackle shelters seems to be enough - that it could accommodate badgers, nest-building birds and termites just as well as it does humans. Stretch the word that thinly and it becomes useless. Some part of him seems to recognise the explanatory poverty of his thesis, for he regularly has recourse to "civilization" and its cognates in their old senses, lapsing into the usage he has derided: specifically, city-building societies with complex political cultures.

Civilizations, though stuffed with what ought to be fascinating historical facts and comparisons, is the sheerest drudgery to read, because Fernandez-Armesto only rarely remembers what he is supposed to be arguing and instead indulges in reams of irrelevant armchair tourism and purple-hued narration. Were his theory a coherent and useful one, in fact, he would have been able to write a much shorter book. The reader at least ought to be grateful that he thinks "culture" cannot explain anything (at least, about half the time he does; as with most of his sweeping statements, he denies it about as often as he asserts it), because his own swerves into that territory are quite shatteringly banal. "Plato fancied himself as a political thinker," we are told facetiously; "Confucius was part of a vibrant world of ideas"; Romanticism is "a scale of values which put emotion above reason"; and Japanese religion "surely represent[s] the way human minds work more typically than westerners of the present generations". What on God's sweet earth can that mean?

Oddly, for all his carefully burnished self-image as a pioneering, multicultural, iconoclastic historian, Fernandez-Armesto's prose is that of a parodic 19th-century buffer, an Anglophile gentleman amateur who congratulates himself on having written his book "in something of a frenzy" informed by "no mature deliberation", who rails constantly against the "gimcrack rubbish" of newfangled inventions such as the electronic watch and (I kid you not) the zippered fly, and who observes the dusty gleam of ancient societies with a patronising inverted snobbery, excusing what was violent, brutish and - yes - uncivilized about them.

Civilizations is, finally, a useful book in one way only: it defines the sensible limits of multiculturalism by overstepping them. Fernandez-Armesto is of course right to emphasise that modern western civilization is not the historically privileged summit of human evolution, but to doubt that it is in every way better than a superstitious ancient culture of South America that regularly sacrificed newborn babies is the most irrational cant of all.

Raymond Illingworth always said Chalkie could bat. It is six years since Craig White first came into the England side as one of his "brave little Yorkie" prospects. He scored a half-century in his second Test and then, in a career that has been on and off more times than the indicators on a car in a local traffic jam, has scarcely scored a run for England since.

Until yesterday that is. On a pitch made for spending the day at the crease White, who came in briefly the previous evening, thought it would be a felony not to take advantage of it. He batted for another four hours, played faultlessly overall, carefully at the start, impeccably against the Patron's XI spin attack and thunderously towards the end when he moved towards his hundred with panache. He was finally caught at the wicket, swishing vigorously, for 120.

In all there were 14 fours and two sixes. One glorious three-ball passage of play that raced him into the 90s saw him drive raspingly straight, through the covers for another boundary and then slide into a lofted off-drive that cleared the boundary fencing and bounced around the concrete terracing. It was as good a shot as any played this tour.

It was, of course, his first hundred in England colours but also his first in any cricket for two years. His bowling, high pace and with wicked use of reverse swing, emerged as the revelation of last season but otherwise these have been lean times.

Having averaged fewer than 20 in first-class cricket in 1999, he suffered a worrying blackout early last summer and played only nine innings for Yorkshire and England. Yesterday's score, made on the back of successive innings of 0, 0 and 0 not out in the recent one-day series, exceeded his summer's aggregate by 20.

Now, with new competition for a Test bowling place alongside Darren Gough and Andy Caddick if a spinner is chosen, White has done his cause no harm, slipping ahead of Dominic Cork. Good on him for that. It was an example - not followed by Mike Atherton on Thursday nor Graeme Hick, unusually, yesterday - of someone recognising a good thing when he saw it.

"I have struggled," he said afterwards." I've been concentrating on my bowling, I think, and worked hard at that to get it reasonably right but the batting has tailed off. I just wanted to spend a bit of time in the middle. If I batted for the first three hours , I thought it might come back to me and that's what I did. The pitch was so good that I said 'I've got to make the most of this' and I set my stall out to bat for most of the day. It helped me that the opposition said a few words to me when I first went in. They thought I was the nightwatchman. That spurred me on."

White shared in partnerships of 83 for both the sixth wicket and the eighth, first with Paul Nixon, who made 31 in his first England innings without looking convincing against the spin, then with Ashley Giles, who looked more confident in making 39 before he was lbw. White had another of 44 for the ninth with Ian Salisbury.

It saw England to 433 all out, a lead on first innnings of 196, which the Patron's XI had reduced by 49 at the close for the loss of Imran Abbas, caught at the wicket off Ian Salisbury. The spinners should hold the key to an England victory today, though there would be a further opportunity for Matthew Hoggard and Cork to exploit the dewfall first thing.

At the start of play it had seemed a certainty that it would be Hick, 77 overnight, who would be celebrating a century. Instead, in the day's second over, he stretched high and far to reach a fastish longhop from Mohammad Sami, and succeeded only in toe-ending it to first slip.

His next few hours would have been spent with his backside in an ice bucket to soothe the bruises where he surely kicked himself.

Let's see if we have got this right. Precisely when Sven-Goran Eriksson takes over the England team depends on Lazio's forthcoming results in Serie A and the Champions League.

So long as Lazio keep winning, the arrival of the first foreigner to run the nation's football team will be delayed until after Eriksson's present contract expires next summer. Two or three defeats in a row, however, and the Swedish technocrat will be here before the month is out.

Against that, the better Lazio do the less chance there will be of Eriksson taking anything more than a temporary interest in England's World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania in March. The Football Association, then, is gambling on Eriksson failing in Rome in the short term so that England's chances will be improved in the long.

Meanwhile Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren - remember them ? - will take England to Turin for a friendly against Italy on Wednesday week. Highly convenient this. Eriksson can pop in to say hello without being accused of taking his eye off the ball at Lazio.

At the same time Tord Grip, Eriksson's assistant at Lazio but now a sort of John the Baptist with the FA, preparing the way for the master's coming, will be compiling a dossier on all things English so that, when Eriksson does take over, he will know his Arsenal from his Middlesbro'.

Thus for the moment England are being run by two casuals whom the FA intends retaining as part-time assistants in the new regime even though Eriksson will obviously regard Grip as his full-time right-hand man.

The three months between the Italy game and the friendly against Spain at Villa Park on February 27 are unlikely to quell speculation about where all this is leading.

At least nobody can accuse Adam Crozier, the bright young thing appointed by the FA as chief executive, of pusillanimity. Crozier is prepared to pay the new coach £10m in the hope that he will build an England team capable of winning the 2006 World Cup, and it seems reasonably safe to assume that Eriksson will prove a better investment than than did the abortive £10m campaign to host the same tournament.

Like all good establishment figures Crozier has wasted little time in distancing the upcoming new order from its immediate predecessor by implying, mildly though significantly, that under Kevin Keegan all was not well in Palookaville.

Crozier thinks the players could be closer together and, remembering the absence of a defensive wall which might have stopped Dietmar Hamann scoring Germany's winning goal at Wembley last month, he might have a point.

Eriksson has already spoken about the need for collectivism and teams thinking with one mind. It seems, therefore, that England will be all the better for some Swedish bondage . . . sorry, bonding.

Since controversy, conflict and confrontation are manna for the media Crozier's words have quickly been taken to assume that rifts in the squad developed during Keegan's short reign: between Liverpool and Manchester United cliques, between those who were in the card school and those who thought that a trump was a bottle blonde with a thick accent.

Well, at least this makes a change from seeing schisms between those who consulted the previous England coach's faith healer and those who believed they had joined the Moonies.

But did not Keegan get the England job largely because he was to football teams what Ralph Reader was to Gang Shows ?

Maybe Keegan's England did not exactly ride along on the crest of the wave but up to and including that first 18 minutes against Portugal in Eindhoven this summer they did appear to be pulling in roughly the same direction.

Keegan failed in Euro 2000 not because the personalities in his team were in conflict but because the football they played had all the harmony of Les Dawson at the piano.

The reality, of course, is that every sporting team in history, football or otherwise, has had its rows and factions but only when the results start to go badly wrong do these begin to surface. No one will realise this more than Eriksson, an old hand at the Italian game where dressing-room infighting can be as entertaining as the Serie A itself.

It is on the field where morale thrives or falters. At the start of the 1970 World Cup in Mexico a furious row broke out in the Italian camp when Gianni Rivera declared that he, and not Sandro Mazzola, should be playing in the opening match. It took the president of the Italian federation, Artemio Franchi, to sort things out, yet Italy went on to reach the final.

Before the 1982 World Cup two of France's leading players were involved in an eternal triangle, which is never calculated to strengthen dressing room bonhomie, but still emerged as the best side in that tournament after Brazil and outplayed West Germany in the semi-finals before going out on penalties.

For England's sake it is to be hoped that Eriksson re-establishes a sense of togetherness. But that will happen only once he starts winning games.

Results and results alone are what matter and it is on these, not the mood in the dressing room, that he will be judged.
